trustfund:
TF093015-NILE BASIN INITIATIVE
            INSTITUTIONAL STRENGTHENING PROJECT

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Institutional
            Strengthening Project (ISP) for Africa were as follows:
            outcomes were moderately satisfactory, the risk to
            development outcome was substantial, the Bank performance
            was moderately satisfactory, and the Grantee performance was
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: it is essential
            to maintain a platform for basin-wide dialogue and to
            continue activities at a technical level in an uncertain
            political context for cooperation. This is a key principle
            for any regional institution owned by its member states. The
            role and added value should be explicit, with the regional
            institution only undertaking activities which cannot be
            undertaken by the individual countries. Overall whilst Nile
            Basin Initiative (NBI) was established by agreement of all
            member states, there is concern that this is faltering and
            potentially fragmenting as a result of losing relevance for
            some countries. NBI is one institution with three centers,
            each forming an important part of the whole, with strength
            together, and respect for subsidiarity. ISP was designed
            with three year duration. With the slow start up (due to
            capacity deficits at the lead Centre which should have been
            foreseen), two key studies were delayed which had knock-on
            efforts throughout the project implementation. The Mid-Term
            Review (MTR) recommended a time extension that enabled the
            NBI to satisfactory complete the project. In general,
            institutional strengthening operations should be of
            sufficient duration to allow for reflection and
            self-learning as part of strengthening.
